course.subject: ENVR
course.name: Energy Sources and Usage
course.description: This course provides students the opportunity to enhance their interdisciplinary understanding of different types of energy resources and their local, regional, and global use. While the focus is on specific fuels and their respective technologies and systems, the course also includes topics on energy transition, energy efficiency, and sustainable consumption. The course also embeds a critical evaluation of energy sources and use with respect to longer-range energy security concerns and contemporary environmental concerns across scales especially the climate emergency.

reviews.author: Diamond
reviews.title: Terrible new professor
reviews.comment_content: The course is not energy-oriented but instead with lots of economic knowledges that were directly copied from the Prof. He's work in ENVR 3410.
reviews.comment_teaching: Unclear explanation on various topics, especially those that are not related to economy. Contents that she claimed not to include in the exam were examined finally, not very punctual and reliable as she forgot to meet students group even though an official appointment was made.
reviews.comment_grading: No clear explanation on how were those group projects examined and graded.
reviews.comment_workload: Fair workload, two assignments, one group project and final exam.

reviews.author: Coral
reviews.comment_content: This  course  examines  recent  developments  in  energy technology  and  markets. It  will introduce  key  concepts  in  environmental  economics  and  apply  economic  reasoning  in analyzing the   real-world   operation   of   oil,   natural   gas,   and   electricity   markets. Understanding  the  structure  of  supply  and  demand  in  these  industries  is  essential  for designing effective energy policy. At the end of  the course  you should be able to gain a basic  understanding  of  the  operation  of  oil,  gas  and  electricity  markets, and  applyeconomic tools to critically analyzea variety of environmental and energy policies.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor's teaching is fair but professor talk softly and peoples love to chat in class so sometimes it is not easy to hear what she is talking. But some answer in midterm is not included in the lecture sides so you have to pay attention in class for the answer.
AND her handwriting on the white board is so ugly so you have to guess what she is writing or drawing sometimes.
reviews.comment_grading:
only the mid term and problem set 1 grades are posted on canvas
even though it is easy but the mean is not high
i got 29/30 (mean 23.9) in mt and 99/100 in problem set 1
but i think our project and my exam are not doing very well (at least not the best in class)
and i got A

Three problem sets: 15%; OPEC Game(project): 15%; Mid-term exam: 30%, final exam: 35%.Class Participation:  5%. The  instructor  reserves  the  right  to  make  small adjustments  to  final  total  grade  score. The  grading  for  the  OPEC  game will  be basedon the performance in the game and memo write-ups.
reviews.comment_workload:
two problem sets, midterm, project and 24hours exam
it takes around 2 hours for each problem set
and the workload of project is light

reviews.author: 姚乔乔
reviews.title: sleepy course
reviews.comment_content: it meaningly talked about econimic stuff. The instructor has a background in economics. She does not konw much about some science and technological abckground about the topics she introduced. She talked about non renewable energy for the first half of the semester and then renewable for the last half.
reviews.comment_teaching: it is quiet boring actually. She made simple powerpoint for courses. Sometimes i cannot recall what she introduced during the class by just looking at her PPT. Her sound is very light. Sometimes you can not hear her voice clearly. That also made me feel sleepy. So I fell asleep.
reviews.comment_grading: grading is ok. About the same with other courses. She shared some of the conculation about the OPEC projects during the game. But the result is very confusing and she made some mistakes about the data she offered
reviews.comment_workload: You have a group project in during the semester. It is very simply, we just mimiced the global oil market for ten days. But that can not reflect the economic model indruced very well in just a few days. After the game every group need to had in a memorandum. Some group members did much more work than others and that can not be reflected because there is no peer evaluation for the group project. Also, we don't know how will she judge about our assignment.

reviews.author: asc4155
reviews.title: Unexpectedly strict grading for a very simple course
reviews.comment_content: Very simple content regarding energy sources with a focus on the environmental, social, political, etc., and other dimensions relevant to the energy transition topic. The content is very easy to understand and not at all technical. Good course to balance out if you have hard courses. Some people may find the absolute lack of challenging material makes the course a little boring.
reviews.comment_teaching: The course is experimenting with blended learning and the delivery of the course is subject to change based on feedback. This semester they had 1 class with a take-home quiz based on reading material and 1 in-person class with a strong focus on debate/discussion. Sometimes the instructor showed his own videos (of him speaking) in class which I found to be a waste of in-class time.
reviews.comment_grading:
GRADING IS FUCKALL. Considering that the course is so easy and you can breeze through it, you would not expect a shit grade. This is the curve:
A range: 8
B range: 20
C range: 20
D/F range: 4
I thought I did very well and was expecting an A or worst case A-, but I received B-. My performance in assessments:
Attendance/Participation: 25/40 (no clue how I scored so low, I was always highly participative)
Essay: 22/25
Infographic: 13/15
Outreach Project: 19/20
Incentive points (seminar attendance): 6/10
Total: 84/110 (B-)
For those taking this course, try not to miss any quiz or class attendance, and hope that your group scores you well on peer assessment (randomly assigned groups) and try and get any incentive points available.
reviews.comment_workload: One of the lowest workload courses I've taken. Some pre-reading materials which have sections highlighted and some pre-recorded videos of the instructor takes max 1 hour to go through and you're prepared for the quiz. Workload slightly increases end of semester since Essay, Infographic, and Outreach Project have the same deadline. However, essay is just 1k words, infographic is based on essay, and outreach project is a 5 minute podcast which is very easy to do. Course attendance is mandatory and has a large impact on your grade (40%)

reviews.author: UEL K.
reviews.title: Overall speaking: Not as good as expected
reviews.comment_content:
• This course provides students with the opportunity to enhance their interdisciplinary understanding of the different types of energy resources and their local, regional, and global use.
• While the focus is on specific fuels and their respective technologies and systems, the course also includes topics on energy transition, energy efficiency, and sustainability.
• The course also embeds a critical evaluation of energy sources and use with respect to longer-range energy security concerns and contemporary environmental concerns across scales especially the climate emergency.

Topics (week+nth lesson) :
1a. Introduction
1b. Energy & Power
2a. Energy Services & Electricity
2b. Energy & Climate Emergency
3a. Doing Energy Research (i.e. citation things)
3b. Energy Transitions
4a. Sunlight Energy
5a. Wind Energy
5b. Case for a 100% RE-powered world
6a. Energy Efficiency & Demand Side Management (DSM)
6b. Coal
7a. Oil
8b. Nuclear Energy
9a. Large Hydropower
9b. Energy Storage
10a. Low-carbon cities
10b. Electric Mobility
11a. Policy for Energy Transition
11b. Markets for Energy Transition
12a. Poverty and Energy Transition
12b. Energy resources and use in the Global South
13a. Accelerating Just Energy Transition
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good: Kind professor
Bad: Poor internet, unclear marking of participation ever since changing the grading method...

Since didn't pay too much attention, no comment for other stuff.
reviews.comment_grading:
Task 1: Attendance/Participation (40%, 2 pts per meeting)

Task 2: 2500-word term paper (40%)
- Any topic interested relating to this class, need to send an email and ask his permission
- APA style
- Turnitin

Task 3: Infographic (20%)
- Extension of Task 2

Incentive: 5 sustainability seminars (1.5-2 pts per meeting, top-up)

My grade: guess yourself but not so good, can check the excel below

(Disclaimer: Did not obtain consent from prof, might remove if asked, so just take as a reference)
reviews.comment_workload:
Highly participative, oral/written discussion per class.

Have reading materials per class.

Slightly touch those energy-related topics (Breadth > Depth), but better have basic knowledge/research-based know-how on them.

reviews.author: ust survivor
reviews.comment_content:
DO NOT BE FOOLED , you WILL need extensive economics understanding or YOU WILL STRUGGLE. THIS IS AN ECONOMICS COURSE.

I specifically asked her if I would be okay taking this course with very little Economics background (this class has no prerequisites, but there should be), and trusted her when she said it would be fine. I WAS WRONG.

Both mid-term and final require economic concepts for essay writing and solving mathematical problems:
Hotelling rule, marginal cost, prisoner's dilemma, market failure etc. Some of the concepts are not mainstream and will require learning simply for this course (my year four friends with economics major did not know them..)

Overall, the content is actually very interesting (esp to ENVR/EVMT students).. however, as our education system tends to, the grading aspect completely ruined the class for me
reviews.comment_teaching:
She tries her best to help you understand but honestly if you are not motivated to learn in your own time... good luck.

For example, she went through the entire principles of microeconomics in one lesson, and oftentimes it is not substantial enough.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pretty harsh slope, mean will get you about a C+..
I got 1 sd above mean for midterm (50%), did assignments and still ended up with a pretty bad grade..
reviews.comment_workload:
Not heavy at all.

One OPEC game where you simply try your best to create numbers, the whole class ends up collaborating in the end.

3 assignments based on lessons

reviews.author: silverfox
reviews.title: Introduction of Energy, Economy, and Environmental
reviews.comment_content:
The content is very engaging and interesting:
- Week 1: introduction to energy basics
- Week 2: Coal, global energy system, and intro to microeconomics
- Week 3: Monopoly, Oligopoly,Oil and Gas Market
- Week 6: Hotelling rule, Hydronuclearetal, Shalegas
- Week 10: Electricity, Storage, Wind and Solar
- Week 12: Electricity market, efficiency and policy

Although the title of the course emphasises the energy side, in fact, the economy problems are mostly discussed. For those who doesn't have economy background may find it hard and struggle.
reviews.comment_teaching: She is very nice and kind. At the beginning she tried to remember all students in the class for class participation. However, the way she teaches is very disorganised. Most of the times she asked questions that she doesn't know the valid answer which left some confusions for us students. She also has very limited background in the science parts and energy which she ended up confusing herself and the students
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is neither strict nor lenient. It really depends on what you write in the essay since it's very subjective.
- 3 assignments: 15%
- OPEC game: 15%
- Mid term: 40%
- Final: 25%
- Class participation: 5%
reviews.comment_workload:
Compared with other courses, this course is very light workload-wise. For the whole semester, there are:
- 3 assignments (short and long questions)
- Mid-term exam (mostly from her powerpoint)
- OPEC Game (this game was very confusing as you have to determine supply of oil every day for 10 consecutive working days; mostly economic problems; at the end you also have to write a group reflection memo)
- Final exam (there was adjustment to 24-hr essay questions; there were 2 long essays not more than 800 words each, opinion essay, and some economic knowledge)

All in all, the workload is not that much and relatively easy but for assignments you will find hardly the answer from powerpoint. So, it's better to come to class

reviews.author: Andrew NKY
reviews.comment_content: The contents cover a wide range of technologies and knowledge in energy usage.
reviews.comment_teaching: K L was very dedicated in teaching and was willing to devote a lot of time to students! He wanted us to learn from project, so he gave us a lot of suggestions on the project and allowed us to think big.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grading. The grading was calculated mostly based on the project. And K L valued a lot on the project, as he wanted us to learn from project.

reviews.author: kllllllllllllll
reviews.title: Fruitful course
reviews.comment_content: Quite good. He has introduced quite a lot of useful concepts into the course, like exergy, LCOE. His assignments are thought-stimulating and are really helping you to understand the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He taught quite fast, without clearly explaining the theories as he assumed you have known them. He spent 15 minutes to finish a 72-page powerpoint and it ended up appearing in the final exam. Sometimes boring.

A good teacher. He will always be very eager to answer students questions and give guidelines and directions for the projects.
reviews.comment_grading: Not bad, a number of students get A- or A.
reviews.comment_workload: 3 assignments, midterm present as well as a final present, project report, final exam

reviews.author: ckp0216
reviews.comment_content: Really really too much content and quite difficult which involved a lots of calculation. Even the professor had not enough time to teach all the content. But no need to worry about memorize the content as the final exam is open book and allow internet access.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. shum is really really really nice guy, although u may feel difficult to understand all the contents well. He is willing to teach you patiently after lesson. He is also very responsible, he is willing to meet with us every single week for our project.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading,
I don't know how was my final exam performance, but the grading for all present was great. Finally B- for myself
reviews.comment_workload:
1 mid term present
1 final present
1 final exam which is open book and allow internet access
1 final project essay (group work)
3 assignments
10% class attendance
